The differential decay rate is dΛ/dw = G{sub F}²/4π³(w²-1){sup 1/2}m{sub D*}³ (m{sub B}-m{sub D*})²G(w)</subfield><subfield code="v">{sub cb}</subfield><subfield code="f">{sub B→D*}(w)</subfield><subfield code="v">{sub cb}</subfield><subfield code=" ">is determined by dividing measurements of dΛ/dw by the phase space and well-known factors, and extrapolating to w → 1. This yields </subfield><subfield code="v">{sub cb}</subfield><subfield code="f">{sub B→D*}(1), and F{sub B→D*}(1) is taken from ''theory''. To date models [1] or a combination of a rigorous inequality plus judgement [2] have been used to estimate F{sub B→D*}(1) - 1. In this work [3] they calculate F{sub B→D*}(1) with lattice gauge theory, in the so-called quenched approximation, but the uncertainty from quenching is included in the error budget.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="536" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="b">AC02-76CH03000</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="7"><subfield code="a">Classical And Quantum Mechanics, General Physics.</subfield><subfield code="2">edbsc</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="7"><subfield code="a">Physics Of Elementary Particles And Fields.</subfield><subfield code="2">edbsc</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="653" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Decay.</subfield><subfield code="a">Phase Space.</subfield><subfield code="a">Physics.</subfield><subfield code="a">Quantum Chromodynamics.</subfield><subfield code="a">Quenching.</subfield><subfield code="a">Symmetry.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="710" ind1="2" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory,</subfield><subfield code="e">researcher.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="710" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">United States.</subfield><subfield code="b">Department of Energy.</subfield><subfield code="b">Office of Energy Research,</subfield><subfield code="e">sponsor.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="710" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">United States.</subfield><subfield code="b">Department of Energy.</subfield><subfield code="b">Office of Scientific and Technical Information,</subfield><subfield code="e">distributor.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="720" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">A.S. Oak Ridge, Tenn. : Distributed by the Office of Scientific and Technical Information, U.S. Dept. of Energy. 178 Kilobytes pages : digital, PDF file. text txt rdacontent computer c rdamedia online resource cr rdacarrier Published through SciTech Connect. 07/12/2002. "fermilab-conf-02/145-t" Flavor Physics and CP Violation, Philadelphia, PA (US), 05/16/2002--05/18/2002. A.S. Kronfeld, P.B. Mackenzie and J.N. S. Free-to-read Unrestricted online access star The authors would like to determine  {sub cb} from the exclusive semi-leptonic decay B→D*lv. The differential decay rate is dΛ/dw = G{sub F}²/4π³(w²-1){sup 1/2}m{sub D*}³ (m{sub B}-m{sub D*})²G(w) {sub cb} {sub B→D*}(w) {sub cb} is determined by dividing measurements of dΛ/dw by the phase space and well-known factors, and extrapolating to w → 1. This yields  {sub cb} {sub B→D*}(1), and F{sub B→D*}(1) is taken from ''theory''. To date models [1] or a combination of a rigorous inequality plus judgement [2] have been used to estimate F{sub B→D*}(1) - 1. In this work [3] they calculate F{sub B→D*}(1) with lattice gauge theory, in the so-called quenched approximation, but the uncertainty from quenching is included in the error budget.
